Born in Bogota on July 3,
1906, President Lleras became a
journalist and was soon known
widely for his writing on political
freedom and democracy. After
serving in various capacities for
his government he was named
Ambassador to the United States
in 1943, then Minister of Foreign
Affairs for the Republic of Colombia, and First Vice-President.
Upon the resignation of President Lopez in 1945, Lleras succeeded to the presidency.
President Lleras is widely
known in the Western Hemisphere for his dedication to the
Pan American movement, especially as Secretary General of the
Organization of American States,
a post he held from 1947 until
1954. In 1955 he relinquished this
position to become president of
the University of the Andes in
Colombia.
In 1957, after the downfall of
the Rojas Pinilla regime in Colombia, a military junta took
governmental responsibility and
called the elections for a constitutional government the next
year. Doctor Lleras effected a bipartisan agreement between the
Liberal and Conservative parties
which assured a moderate and
stable government. He was elected
in May 1958, and took office in
August.
According to the Embassy of
Colombia, the two traditional
political parties, the Conservatives and the Liberals, have entered into a political truce
whereby each enjoy equal representation and power in all
branches of government.
The presidency passes from
one party to the other at the end
of each four year term. Lleras
is a Liberal and will be succeeded
by a Conservative' in 1962. The
truce will last for 16 years when
conditions will be stable enough
to permit normal political com-,
petition.

political institutions.

subjects such as crew-served
weapons instruction, will be
taught during the six-week summer .camp period, normally attended during the junior and
senior college years.
According to Major William
W. Woodside of the Hopkins
ROTC, the new program "will
stimulate increased intellectual
attainment on the part of the
ROTC students; lessen the training load on students, particularly those pursuing technical
degrees; and make the overall
program more attractive."
